{{good article}} {{For|the community in Pennsylvania named Roaring Creek|Roaring Creek Township, Columbia County, Pennsylvania}} {{Infobox river | name = Roaring Creek | image = Roaring Creek looking downstream near its mouth.JPG | image_caption = Roaring Creek looking downstream near its mouth | name_native = Popemetang | source1_location = Catawissa Mountain in Roaring Creek Township, Columbia County, Pennsylvania | mouth_location = Susquehanna River on the border between Mayberry Township, Montour County, Pennsylvania and Franklin Township, Columbia County, Pennsylvania | mouth_lat_d = 40.9395 | mouth_long_d = -76.5289 | mouth_coord_format= dms | mouth_coord_region= US-PA | progression = Susquehanna River â†’ [[Chesapeake Bay]] | etymology = direct translation of its native name, Popemetang, which references the rapids and waterfalls on the creek | length = {{convert|20|mi|km|abbr=on}} | source1_elevation = between {{convert|1660|and|1680|ft|m}} | mouth_elevation = {{convert|453|ft|m|abbr=on}} | basin_size = {{convert|87.3|sqmi|km2|abbr=on}} | tributaries_left = [[Lick Run (Roaring Creek)|Lick Run]], [[South Branch Roaring Creek]] | tributaries_right = [[Mill Creek (Roaring Creek)|Mill Creek]] }} '''Roaring Creek''' is a [[tributary]] of the [[Susquehanna River]] in [[Columbia County, Pennsylvania|Columbia County]] and [[Montour County, Pennsylvania|Montour County]], in [[Pennsylvania]], in the United States. It is slightly more than {{convert|20|mi|km}} long and flows through [[Roaring Creek Township, Columbia County, Pennsylvania|Roaring Creek Township]], [[Locust Township, Columbia County, Pennsylvania|Locust Township]], [[Catawissa Township, Columbia County, Pennsylvania|Catawissa Township]], [[Cleveland Township, Columbia County, Pennsylvania|Cleveland Township]], and [[Franklin Township, Columbia County, Pennsylvania|Franklin Township]] in Columbia County and [[Mayberry Township, Montour County, Pennsylvania|Mayberry Township]] in Montour County.<ref name = "nationalmap">{{Citation|author = [[United States Geological Survey]]|url = http://viewer.nationalmap.gov/viewer/|title = The National Map Viewer|accessdate = April 11, 2015}}</ref> The [[drainage basin|watershed]] of the creek has an area of {{convert|87.3|sqmi|km2}}. It has three named tributaries: South Branch Roaring Creek, Lick Run, and Mill Creek. The creek is not considered to be impaired and is not affected by coal mining. However, its watershed has been impacted by human land use. [[Claystone]]s, [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerates]], [[sandstone]]s, [[siltstone]]s, and [[shale]]s all occur within the watershed. The creek flows through a gorge in its lower reaches, along the border between Columbia County and Montour County.
Most of the watershed of Roaring Creek is in Columbia County, but small areas are in Montour County, Northumberland County, and Schuylkill County. More than 40 percent of the watershed is forested and nearly 40 percent is agricultural land. State game lands and state forests are also in the watershed. A total of approximately 3,500 people inhabit the watershed, as of 2000. The creek's drainage basin is a High-Quality Coldwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery upstream of Lick Run. Downstream of Lick Run, the main stem is a Trout Stocked Fishery and Migratory Fishery. A reach of the creek above Lick Run is designated as [[Class A Wild Trout Waters]]. 31 species of fish were observed at 20 sites in the watershed in 2003 and 2004.
Roaring Creek was historically known as Popemetang, but it was known as Roaring Creek by the late 1700s. Settlers such as [[Quaker]]s first arrived in the area in the 1770s. In the 19th century, various mills and furnaces were constructed on the creek and several bridges were constructed. Agriculture was also a major industry in the watershed in the early 20th century. More bridges were constructed across the creek in the 20th century. The Roaring Creek Valley Conservation Association formed in February 2006. Part of the creek is navigable by canoe.
==Course== [[File:Roaring Creek (Pennsylvania) in springtime.JPG|thumb|left|Roaring Creek in springtime]] Roaring Creek begins on [[Catawissa Mountain]] in Roaring Creek Township, Columbia County. It flows west-southwest for a short distance before turning south for a few tenths of a mile. It then turns west for a few miles and flows off Catawissa Mountain before eventually crossing State Route 2003, passing Mill Grove, and entering Locust Township. The creek turns north-northwest for a few tenths of a mile and reenters Roaring Creek Township before turning west and reentering Locust Township. It then flows west-northwest for more than a mile and receives Mill Creek, its first named tributary, from the [[wikt:right bank|right]], as well as receiving the tributary Lick Run from the [[wikt:left bank|left]]. The creek then turns northwest for more than a mile and enters [[Slabtown, Pennsylvania|Slabtown]] before turning west for several tenths of a mile and crossing [[Pennsylvania Route 42]]. After this, it turns northwest for several tenths of a mile before meandering west-southwest for a few miles, passing Queen City, Parrs Mill, and a lake known as [[Lake Glory]]. In this stretch, the creek leaves Locust Township and crosses the border between Catawissa Township and Cleveland Township three or four times before entering Franklin Township. Near Pennsyl's Mill, The creek then [[meander]]s northwest for a few miles, crossing [[Pennsylvania Route 487]] and receiving South Branch Roaring Creek, its least named tributary, from the left. Upon reaching the Montour County line, the creek turns north for a few miles, flowing along the border between Franklin Township, Columbia County and Mayberry Township, Montour County. In this reach, it passes through a gorge with Sharp Ridge on the west. After a few miles, the creek leaves the gorge and crosses State Route 3012. A few tenths of a mile further downstream, it reaches its confluence with the Susquehanna River.<ref name = "nationalmap"/>
Roaring Creek joins the Susquehanna River {{convert|142.36|mi|km}} upriver of its mouth.<ref name = "gaz">{{Citation|publisher = [[Lycoming University]]|url = http://www.lycoming.edu/cwi/pdfs/paGazetterOfStreams.pdf|title = Pennsylvania Gazetteer of Streams|pages = 85, 100, 120, 132|date = November 2, 2001|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref>
===Tributaries=== Roaring Creek has three named tributaries: South Branch Roaring Creek, Lick Run, and Mill Creek.<ref name = "nationalmap"/> South Branch Roaring Creek joins Roaring Creek {{convert|4.28|mi|km}} upstream of its mouth. Its watershed has an area of {{convert|35.9|sqmi|km2}}. Lick Run joins Roaring Creek {{convert|14.08|mi|km}} upstream of its mouth. Its watershed has an area of {{convert|5.97|sqmi|km2}}. Mill Creek joins Roaring Creek {{convert|15.02|mi|km}} upstream of its mouth. Its watershed has an area of {{convert|4.98|sqmi|km2}}.<ref name = "gaz"/>
==Hydrology== The concentration of [[alkalinity]] in Roaring Creek upstream of Lick Run is 9 milligrams per liter.<ref name = "classa">{{Citation|author = [[Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission]]|url = http://fishandboat.com/classa.pdf|title = Class A Wild Trout Waters|page = 17|date = December 16, 2013|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> Many nearby watersheds have been rendered nearly devoid of [[aquatic life]] due to [[acid mine drainage]] caused by [[coal mining]]. However, Roaring Creek has not been affected by this, although it has been still impacted by human land use. [[Sedimentation]], [[siltation]], and agricultural impacts occur in the watershed. The only impaired stream in the watershed is a small unnamed tributary that is impaired by siltation. From a chemical standpoint, Roaring Creek is infertile.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/>
The [[specific conductance]] of Roraing Creek ranges from 11 [[siemens (unit)|micro-siemens]] per centimeter at site 2 to 127 micro-siemens per centimeter at site 4. In 2003 and 2004, the [[pH]] of the creek ranged from 7.0 to 7.2. In a later survey, it was found to be acidic at sites 1 and 2 (6.50 and 6.89, respectively), but alkaline at sites 3 and 4 (7.34 and 8.27, respectively). The concentration of [[alkalinity]] in the creek ranges from 5.1 milligrams per liter at site 1 to 32 milligrams per liter at site 2. The concentration of [[water hardness]] ranges from 28 milligrams per liter at river mile 4.04 to 44 milligrams per liter at river mile 8.54. The [[discharge (hydrology)|discharge]] of the creek is 12.2 liters per second at site 1, 243.5 liters per second at site 2, 216.7 liters per second at site 3, and 271.6 liters per second at site 4.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/>
The concentration of [[nitrogen]] in Roaring Creek ranges from 956.5 micrograms per liter at site 1 to 2343.1 micrograms per liter at site 2. The [[phosphorus]] concentration ranges from 12.6 micrograms per liter at site 1 to 28.6 micrograms per liter at site 2.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/>
==Geography, geology, and climate== [[File:Roaring Creek looking upstream near its mouth.JPG|thumb|Roaring Creek near the lower end of its gorge]] The elevation near the [[river mouth|mouth]] of Roaring Creek is {{convert|453|ft|m}} above [[sea level]].<ref name = "gnis">{{Citation|author = [[Geographic Names Information System]]|url = http://gnis.usgs.gov/apex/f?p=136:3:0::NO:3:P3_FID,P3_TITLE:1185166,Roaring%20Creek|title = Feature Detail Report for: Roaring Creek|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> The elevation of the creek's [[river source|source]] is between {{convert|1660|and|1680|ft|m}} above sea level.<ref name = "nationalmap"/> From {{convert|1100|to|700|ft|m}} above sea level, the gradient of the creek is 57.1 feet per mile. From {{convert|700|ft|m}} above sea level to its mouth, the gradient is 25.7 feet per mile.<ref name = "waterresources"/>
The [[topography]] at the [[headwaters]] of Roaring Creek is mountainous. However, much of the watershed is rough and hilly and the creek flows through a valley surrounded by broken hills. It flows through a narrow [[gorge]] for its last {{convert|3|mi|km}}. The creek's [[stream channel|channel]] is [[sinuous]].<ref name = "waterresources">{{Citation|author = Water Supply Commission of Pennsylvania|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-mM_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA609#v=onepage&q=%22Roaring%20Creek%22&f=false|title = Water Resources Inventory Report ..., Parts 1-5|page = 529|year = 1921|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> There are cobbly and rocky rapids on some reaches of the creek. In the gorge, the creek flows past cliffs and over ledges and [[waterfall]]s.<ref name = "gertler"/> A set of wet [[limestone]] ledges known as the Roaring Creek Bluffs are located along the creek in Franklin Township and Montour County.<ref name = "inventory">{{Citation|author = The Pennsylvania Science Office of [[The Nature Conservancy]]|url = http://www.naturalheritage.state.pa.us/CNAI_PDFs/Columbia%20County%20NAI%202004.pdf|title = Columbia County Natural Areas Inventory 2004|pages = 32, 50, 91|year = 2004|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> Power lines also cross the creek in this reach. Some strainers occur on the creek upstream of State Route 3012.<ref name = "gertler"/> A [[ridge]] known as [[Sharp Ridge]] is located near the creek.<ref name = "annals"/>
Roaring Creek is located in the [[ridge and valley]] physiographic province.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> A dividing ridge separates the creek from the Susquehanna River.<ref name = "annals"/> One reach of the creek is a mid-sized coldwater stream. Another reach is a large [[freestone stream]].<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> Roaring Creek flows through [[rock formation]]s consisting of [[sandstone]] and [[shale]].<ref name = "waterresources"/> Rocks in the watershed include [[claystone]]s, [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerates]], sandstones, [[siltstone]]s, and shales from the [[Devonian]] and [[Mississippian (geology)|Mississippian]]. Outcroppings of calcareous beds, limestones, and marine fossils occur in the watershed as well. Some mineable [[coal]] is present in the watershed of South Branch Roaring Creek.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> The Genesee beds appear along the creek and are the lowest beds that are visible above the water line. To the east, they are covered by Chemung beds.<ref name = "battle">{{Citation|editor = J.H. Battle|publisher = A. Warner & Company|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CMwwAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA2&dq=%22Roaring+Creek%22+%22columbia+county%22+pa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rbkqVaHpDouYgwT3qYHoDQ&ved=0CE8Q6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%22Roaring%22%20&f=false|title = History of Columbia and Montour Counties, Pennsylvania|pages = 21, 298, 304|year = 1887|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> A [[soil]] known as the Albrights Series is found along the creek. It is a reddish-brown soil that is slightly poorly or moderately well drained and is made from glaciated red shale and sandstone.<ref name = "soil survey">{{Citation|author = Paul H. Parrish|publisher = U.S. Dept. of Agriculture, Soil Conservation Service|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=YSMNAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA138&dq=%22Roaring+Creek%22+%22columbia+county%22+pa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SxUrVbz_N8GLNvySgqAH&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=%22Roaring%20Creek%22&f=false|title = Soil survey, Columbia County, Pennsylvania: Report|pages = 26, 69|year = 1967|accessdate = April 13, 2015}}</ref>
Roaring Creek has a [[100 year flood|100 year]] [[floodplain]].<ref name = "comprehensiveplan"/> The average annual rate of precipitation in the watershed of Roaring Creek ranges from {{convert|35|to|50|in|cm}}.<ref name = "waterresources"/> In July 2003 and June 2004, the water temperature of the creek was found to range from {{convert|14.7|C|F}} at [[river mile]] 10.98 to {{convert|19.4|C|F}} at river mile 6.02. The air temperature near the creek ranged from {{convert|17.0|C|F}} at river mile 8.54 to {{convert|30.0|C|F}} at river mile 6.02.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/>
==Watershed== [[File:Roaring Creek in its upper reaches (1).JPG|thumb|left|Roaring Creek in its upper reaches]] The [[drainage basin|watershed]] of Roaring Creek has an area of {{convert|87.3|sqmi|km2}}.<ref name = "gaz"/> The watershed occupies parts of Columbia County, Montour County, [[Northumberland County, Pennsylvania|Northumberland County]], and [[Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania|Schuylkill County]].<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/><ref name = "waterresources"/> Most of the watershed is in Columbia County and smaller areas are in Montour County and Northumberland County. Only a very small area in the its upper reaches is in Schuylkill County.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> The watershed is in the Lower North Branch Susquehanna drainage basin.<ref name = "waterresources"/> The creek's mouth is in the [[United States Geological Survey]] quadrangle of Danville. However, its source is in the quadrangle of Shumans. The creek also passes through the quadrangle of Catawissa.<ref name = "gnis"/> Other quadrangles that the watershed is in include Shamokin, Ashland, and Mount Carmel.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> The creek flows in a generally northwesterly direction and serves as the [[county line|border]] between Montour County and Columbia County in its last {{convert|2|mi|km}}.<ref name = "waterresources"/> Roaring Creek is one of three major streams draining the southern part of Columbia County.<ref name = "annals">{{Citation|author = J.H. Beers|publisher = J.H. Beers & Company|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jEkVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA398&dq=%22Roaring+Creek%22+%22columbia+county%22+pa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rbkqVaHpDouYgwT3qYHoDQ&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22Roaring%22&f=false|title = Historical and Biographical Annals of Columbia and Montour Counties, Pennsylvania|pages = 19, 22â€“25, 231, 370, 398, 495|year = 1915|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref>
More than 40 percent of the watershed of Roaring Creek is on [[forest]]ed land, including [[evergreen]] and [[deciduous]] forests, as well as [[mixed forest]]s. A significant portion of the forested land in the watershed is a {{convert|9000|acre|ha}} tract of land along South Branch Roaring Creek. This tract was acquired by the [[Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources]] in 2003.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> A large tract of forested land on a ridge running from [[Moosic, Pennsylvania|Moosic]] to the Susquehanna River passes through the watershed of Roaring Creek.<ref name = "inventory"/> [[State forest]] land occurs along the southern edge of the watershed and [[Pennsylvania State Game Lands]] ([[Pennsylvania State Game Lands Number 58]]) occur along the eastern edge. Nearly 40 percent of the watershed is on [[agriculture|agricultural]] land.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> This land use occurs in the creek's valley, as does open space.<ref name = "comprehensiveplan"/>
Upstream of Lick Run, 13 percent of Roaring Creek is on public land that is open to access. The remaining 87 percent is on private land that is closed to access.<ref name = "classa"/> The remaining reaches of the creek are entirely on private land, but open to access. As of 2000, approximately 3,500 people live in the watershed. In section 01, the population density of the watershed is 18 people per square kilometer as of 2000. In section 02, the population density is 22 people per square kilometer and in section 03, the population density is 16 people per square kilometer. In section 01 of the creek, 50 percent of its length is within 100 meters of a road, 89 percent is within 300 meters, and 91 percent is within 500 meters. In section 02, 28 percent is within 100 meters, 87 percent is within 300 meters, and 100 percent is within 500 meters. In section 03, 96 percent of its length is within 100 meters of a road, 98 percent is within 300 meters of one, and 100 percent is within 500 meters of one.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> The creek flows through a remote-seeming farm valley for a substantial part of its length.<ref name = "gertler"/> Major roads in or near the watershed include [[Pennsylvania Route 487]], [[Pennsylvania Route 54]], and [[Pennsylvania Route 42]].<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/>
Visual assessment of Roaring Creek was carried out by Roaring Creek Valley Conservation Association volunteers at four locations in October and November 2007. The scores ranged from 15.5 out of 28 (55 percent; the lowest value in the entire watershed) to 23 out of 28 (82 percent).<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/>
==History and etymology== Roaring Creek was entered into the [[Geographic Names Information System]] on August 2, 1979. Its identifier in the Geographic Names Information System is 1185166.<ref name = "gnis"/>
Roaring Creek was known to the [[Lenni Lenape]] as ''Popemetang'', which means "Roaring Creek" in English.<ref name = "placenames"/> This name likely originates from the waterfalls and rapids on the creek's lower reaches.<ref name = "200years"/> The creek was known as Popemetang until the late 1700s. However, several maps were referring to it as Roaring Creek as early as 1792.<ref name = "placenames">{{Citation|author = [[Walter M. Brasch]]|publisher = Columbia County Historical Society|title = Columbia County Place Names|page = 185|year = 1982}}</ref> Its name appears as Roaring Creek in even the earliest survey warrants in the area.<ref name = "battle"/>
The Centre Turnpike was constructed in 1770 and provided access to the valley of Roaring Creek, roughly following the current course of Pennsylvania Route 487 and Pennsylvania Route 54. The [[Reading Road]] was later constructed in the watershed and ran in a southeasterly direction.<ref name = "200years"/> [[Quaker]]s were living in the valley of the creek by the 1770s and land on the creek was patented to Samuel Shakespeare in 1773.<ref name = "annals"/><ref name = "200years"/> A number of settlers arrived in the valley from the [[Philadelphia]] area via the Reading Road.<ref name = "200years">{{Citation|author = Edwin M. Barton|publisher = Columbia County Bicentennial Commission, Columbia County Historical Society |url = https://archive.org/stream/columbiacountytw00bart/columbiacountytw00bart_djvu.txt|title = Full text of "Columbia County two hundred years ago"|year = 1976|accessdate = April 12, 2015|via = [[archive.org]]}}</ref> Soon after the end of the [[American Revolutionary War]], farms were appearing along the creek's banks.<ref name = "comprehensiveplan">{{Citation|author = Nassaux-Hemsley, Inc.|url = http://elibrary.pacounties.org/Documents/Columbia_County/2597;%20Columbia%20County/4203700000ccp.pdf|title = Comprehensive Plan Phase I Background Studes Columbia County, Pennsylvania|pages = 17, 108, 129, 143|date = August 3, 1993|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref>
The second-oldest [[watermill|mill]] in what is now Columbia County was built in a gorge on Roaring Creek, near its mouth, in the 1780s.<ref name = "americanmiller"/> This mill was known as the Cleaver Mill.<ref name = "200years"/> A second mill, which was similar to the first, was later constructed at the site.<ref name = "americanmiller">{{Citation|work = [[The American Miller]]|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wM1FAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA193&lpg=PA193&dq=%22Roaring+Creek%22+%22columbia+county%22+pa&source=bl&ots=-FZP8kiGsn&sig=wdOcHcytt43a1o7K1KmWavjDo5o&hl=en&sa=X&ei=uagqVbSZCYi8ggSzm4GYBg&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBzgU#v=onepage&q=%22Roaring%20Creek%22%20%22columbia%20county%22%20pa&f=false|title = American Miller and Processor, Volume 43, Issues 1-6|page = 193|year = 1915|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> John Hauch constructed a furnace on the creek in 1816. It was the first furnace in the area.<ref>{{Citation|author = Sherman Day|publisher = G. W. Gorton|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=AEIVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA244&dq=%22Roaring+Creek%22+%22columbia+county%22+pa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YbMrVYqqPMLvggS1yYGwCw&ved=0CFQQ6AEwCTgo#v=onepage&q=%22Roaring%20Creek%22%20%22columbia%20county%22%20pa&f=false|title = Historical Collections of the State of Pennsylvania|page = 244|year = 1843|accessdate = April 13, 2015}}</ref> The first [[iron furnace]] in Montour County was built near the creek's mouth in 1839 or 1840.<ref name = "annals"/><ref name = "iron">{{Citation|author = J. Peter Lesley|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=g94LAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA20&dq=%22Roaring+Creek%22+%22columbia+county%22+pa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=D7IrVaSzBMmagwTDyIDYDw&ved=0CEUQ6AEwCDgU#v=onepage&q=%22Roaring%20Creek%22%20%22columbia%20county%22%20pa&f=false|title = The Iron Manufacturer's Guide to the Furnaces, Forges and Rolling Mills of the United States|page = 90|accessdate = April 13, 2015}}</ref> The furnace was known as the Roaring Creek Anthracite Water Power Furnace. It was altered in 1854. In 1856, the furnace produced 2350 tons of iron from ore on [[Montour Ridge]], despite low water.<ref name = "iron"/> The only [[post office]] in Mayberry Township up to 1915 was built at the mouth of the creek in 1895. It was known as Howelsville, after W.B. Howell, its first postmaster.<ref name = "annals"/>
In the early 1900s, major industries in the watershed of Roaring Creek included [[agriculture]]. However, the creek was also used as [[water power]] for a small [[gristmill]]. During this time period, major communities in the watershed included Roaring Creek and Bear Gap. Their populations were 407 and 124, respectively.<ref name = "waterresources"/> In the early 1900s, the only major industries in Franklin Township were gristmills on the creek on the border between it and Cleveland Township. There were historically proposals to use the creek as a [[water supply]] for [[Danville, Pennsylvania|Danville]], transferring the water via [[pipe (fluid conveyance)|pipes]] under the Susquehanna River.<ref name = "annals"/> Andrew Trone once constructed a hotel on the creek.<ref name = "battle"/>
Many bridges have been constructed across Roaring Creek and a number of [[covered bridge]]s can be seen from the creek.<ref name = "gertler"/><ref name = "uglybridges"/> The first bridge over the creek was constructed in 1874 at Slabtown for a cost of $1500. It was replaced in 1913 for a cost of $5500.<ref name = "annals"/> The [[Davis Covered Bridge]] was built northwest of Slabtown in 1875 and repaired in 1997. It is {{convert|86.9|ft|m}} long and is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The [[Snyder Covered Bridge No. 17]] was built over the creek southeast of Slabtown in 1876 and repaired in 2010. It is {{convert|60.0|ft|m}} long and is also on the National Register of Historic Places. The two-span [[Esther Furnace Covered Bridge]] was built over the creek in Cleveland Township in 1905. It is {{convert|95.1|ft|m}} long and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.<ref name = "uglybridges">{{Citation|url = http://www.uglybridges.com/pa/columbia/|title = Columbia County|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref>
A steel stringer/multi-beam or girder bridge carrying State Route 2012 was constructed over Roaring Creek in 1908 and repaired in 1996. It is {{convert|27.9|ft|m}} long and is situated east of Mill Grove. A concrete [[tee beam]] bridge was built over the creek in 1940 north of [[Aristes, Pennsylvania|Aristes]]. This bridge is {{convert|33.1|ft|m}} long and carries Pennsylvania Route 42. A two-span steel stringer/multi-beam or girder bridge carrying State Route 3003 was constructed across the creek southwest of [[Catawissa, Pennsylvania|Catawissa]] in 1950 and repaired in 2011. This bridge is {{convert|86.0|ft|m}} long. Two bridges of the same type (but with only one span) were constructed over the creek in Slabtown and Mill Grove in 1956, carrying Creek Road and State Route 2001. Their lengths are {{convert|64.0|ft|m}} and {{convert|46.9|ft|m}}; the first was repaired in 2011. A prestressed [[box beam]] or girders bridge carrying Pennsylvania Route 42 over the creek was built in 1959 south of Catawissa. Its length is {{convert|68.9|ft|m}} and it was repaired in 2010. A bridge of a similar type was built over the creek in 1964 for T314. It is {{convert|73.2|ft|m}} long and is situated to the south of Catawissa. A prestressed stringer/multi-beam or girder bridge carrying State Route 3012 was built across the creek in 1966. It is west of Catawissa and is {{convert|64.0|ft|m}} long. A prestressed box beam or girders bridge was built across the creek in 1974 south of Catawissa. It is {{convert|84.0|ft|m}} long and carries Pennsylvania Route 487. A bridge of the same type, but carrying T468, was built over the creek in 1981. It is situated south of Mill Grove and has a length of {{convert|50.9|ft|m}}. A steel stringer/multi-beam or girder bridge carrying Mill Road was built over the creek in 1985 and repaired in 2012. This bridge is {{convert|34.1|ft|m}} long and is situated southeast of Slabtown.<ref name = "uglybridges"/>
In 2003, Martin Friday assessed streams in the watershed of Roaring Creek at 37 locations, using the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|United States Environmental Protection Agency's]] rapid assessment protocol. In 2004, Robert Wnuk carried out fisheries surveys on every named stream in the watershed. The [[Roaring Creek Valley Conservation Association]] formed in February 2006 to conserve the natural and cultural resources of the Roaring Creek watershed.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage">{{Citation|author = Catherine D. Haffner & Roaring Creek Valley Conservation Association|url = http://www.coldwaterheritage.org/docs/2007-grantees/roaring-creek.pdf|title = ROARING CREEK WATERSHED COLDWATER CONSERVATION PLAN COLUMBIA COUNTY, PA|pages = 3â€“5, 7, 14â€“16, 25, 32, 35, 42, 49, 61â€“63, 73|date = February 19, 2009|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref>
==Biology== Upstream of the tributary Lick Run, the drainage basin of Roaring Creek is designated as a High-Quality Coldwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery. From Lick Run downstream to its mouth, the [[main stem]] of the creek is a Trout-Stocking Fishery and a Migratory Fishery.<ref>{{Citation|work = [[Pennsylvania Code]]|url = http://www.pacode.com/secure/data/025/chapter93/s93.9k.html|title = Â§ 93.9k. Drainage List K. Susquehanna River Basin in Pennsylvania Susquehanna River|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> Wild [[trout]] naturally reproduce in the creek from its headwaters downstream to {{convert|11154|ft|m}} upstream of its mouth, a distance of {{convert|18.15|mi|km}}. They also naturally reproduce throughout the entire length of every other named tributary of the creek.<ref>{{Citation|author = [[Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission]]|url = http://fishandboat.com/trout_repro.pdf|title = Pennsylvania Wild Trout Waters (Natural Reproduction) - Jan 2015|pages = 29â€“30|date = January 2015|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> Roaring Creek is considered by the [[Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission]] to be Class A Wild Trout Waters for [[brown trout]] from its headwaters downstream to Lick Run, a distance of {{convert|6.1|mi|km}}.<ref name = "classa"/>
In 2003 and 2004, 31 fish species were found at 20 sites in the watershed of Roaring Creek. [[Blacknose dace]] are the most common fish species in the watershed and were observed at 85 percent of the sites. [[White sucker]]s and brown trout occurred at 80 percent of the sites, [[longnose dace]] occurred at 70 percent of the sites, [[cutlips minnow]]s occurred at 65 percent of the sites, and [[bluegill]]s occurred at 60 percent of the sites. [[Fallfish]], [[golden shiner]]s, [[yellow bullhead]]s, and [[American eel]]s were all historically observed in the watershed, but were not found during the survey. However, [[redside dace]], [[creek chubsucker]]s, [[green sunfish]], and [[fathead minnow]]s were observed in the watershed for the first time during the 2003/2004 survey. The most common game species was wild brown trout, although smaller numbers of [[brook trout]] were observed as well. Other game fish in the creek's drainage basin include [[rainbow trout]]. [[smallmouth bass]], [[largemouth bass]], and [[chain pickerel]].<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/>
The [[biomass (ecology)|biomass]] of wild brown trout in section 02 of Roaring Creek was estimated in the early 2000s to be 9.53 kilograms per hectare. There were an estimated 42 brown trout of legal size per kilometer of stream. This equates to an estimated 815 brown trout between {{convert|7|and|16|in|cm}} in length in that section. The trout in section 02 of the creek are up to approximately {{convert|400|mm|in}} in length and some brown trout in the creek can reach lengths of up to {{convert|22|in|cm}}.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/><ref>{{Citation|author = [[Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission]]|url = http://fishandboat.com/images/fisheries/afm/2004/4_06-10roaring.htm|title = Roaring Creek (Stocked Area) Columbia County June 2004|date = June 2004|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref>
[[Waterfowl]] have been known to inhabit the watershed of Roaring Creek.<ref name = "soil survey"/>
Various [[macroinvertebrate]] taxa inhabit Roaring Creek. At one site, there is one abundant macroinvertebrate taxon, with 25 to 100 individuals being observed. At this site, there are five common taxa and five present taxa, with 10 to 25 and 3 to 9 individuals being observed, respectively. Eleven taxa are rare, with fewer than three individuals being observed. At another site, there are two abundant taxa, three common taxa, four present taxa, and eight rare taxa. At a third site on the creek, there are three abundant taxa, four common taxa, three present taxa, and seven rare taxa.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/>
[[Hardwood]] trees and [[tsuga|hemlocks]] occur on the slopes of the valley of Roaring Creek. Hemlocks also occur in the creek's gorge.<ref name = "gertler"/> The canopy coverage at four sites on the creek ranges from 0 percent to 75 percent. The [[algae|algal]] biomass of the creek ranges from 0.01 to 1.21 in terms of [[chlorophyll a]] per square centimeter.<ref name = "coldwaterheritage"/> The Roaring Creek Bluffs are listed on the Columbia County Natural Areas Inventory. [[Dodecatheon radicatum|Jeweled shooting-star]], which is threatened in Pennsylvania, occurs at this site.<ref name = "inventory"/> Other plant species in this area include [[hydrangea]], [[fragile fern]], [[maidenhair spleenwort]], [[golden saxifrage]]. However, several [[weed]]y plants also grow in the area.<ref name = "inventory"/>
==Recreation== It is possible to [[canoe]] on {{convert|13.0|mi|km}} of Roaring Creek, from Slabtown to the mouth during fast [[snowmelt]] or within three days of heavy rain. The difficulty rating of the creek ranges from 1 to 2+. Edward Gertler's book ''Keystone Canoeing'' describes the scenery as being "fair to good". The book describes the creek itself as being "a small and easy-to-overlook wet weather stream". There are two painted canoe gauges on the creek, one at Pennsylvania Route 42 and the other at Pennsylvania Route 487.<ref name = "gertler">{{Citation|author = Edward Gertler|publisher = Seneca Press|title = Keystone Canoeing|page = 233|year = 1984}}</ref>
Roaring Creek is one of the major fishing area in Columbia County.<ref>{{Citation|author = Columbia-Montour Visitors' Bureau|url = http://www.itourcolumbiamontour.com/outdoors-to-explore/fishing-reel-em-in/|title = Fishing â€“ Reel Em' In|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> [[Knoebels Amusement Resort|Knoebels Amusement Park]] is in the western part of the creek's watershed.<ref>{{Citation|url = http://www.rcvca.org/Map.pdf|title = Roaring Creek Watershed Columbia County, PA|accessdate = April 12, 2015}}</ref> In the 1990s, the creek was a candidate for [[Pennsylvania Scenic Rivers]] status.<ref name = "comprehensiveplan"/>
